title: Lightly Obscured
subtitle: Disadvantage on some checks
description: Dim light, patchy fog, or moderate foliage can create a lightly obscured area.
bullets: A creature in a lightly obscured area has disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.
When you attack a target you can't see clearly, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. This applies if your target is in a lightly obscured area.
Hiding is not possible in a lightly obscured area unless you are also behind at least three-quarters cover.

title: Heavily Obscured
subtitle: Effectively blinded
description: Darkness, opaque fog, or dense foliage creates a heavily obscured area.
bullets: A creature in a heavily obscured area effectively suffers from the Blinded condition when trying to see anything in that area.
This means it automatically fails ability checks requiring sight, has disadvantage on its attack rolls, and attack rolls against it have advantage.
A creature can always attempt to Hide while in a heavily obscured area.

title: Bright Light
subtitle: Normal vision
description: Bright light lets most creatures see normally.
bullets: Sources include direct sunlight, the area of a Daylight spell, or the immediate vicinity of torches and lanterns.
Some creatures have Sunlight Sensitivity, giving them disadvantage on d20 Tests while in direct sunlight.

title: Dim Light
subtitle: Lightly obscured
description: Dim light, also called shadows, creates a lightly obscured area.
bullets: Creatures in dim light have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.
Natural sources include twilight, dawn, or a full moon.
Creatures with Darkvision treat dim light as if it were bright light.

title: Darkness
subtitle: Heavily obscured
description: Darkness creates a heavily obscured area.
bullets: Creatures without special senses are effectively Blinded in darkness.

Creatures with Darkvision can see in nonmagical darkness within a specified range as if it were dim light (meaning they still have disadvantage on Perception checks). They cannot discern color in darkness.
Magical darkness, such as from the Darkness spell, blocks even Darkvision.

title: Blindsight
subtitle: Perceive without sight
description: A creature with Blindsight can perceive its surroundings without relying on sight, within a specific radius.
bullets: Within its radius, the creature can effectively 'see' everything that is not behind total cover, even in magical darkness. It can also see invisible creatures.
It is effective against visual illusions.
A creature with Blindsight is still subject to the Blinded condition if its non-visual sense is impaired (e.g., a bat in an area of magical silence).

title: Darkvision
subtitle: Limited vision in darkness
description: A creature with darkvision can see in dim light and darkness.
bullets: Within its specified range, a creature with darkvision can see in dim light as if it were bright light.
It can see in darkness as if it were dim light. This means the area is still Lightly Obscured for them, imposing disadvantage on Perception checks.
The creature can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.
Darkvision does not penetrate magical darkness.

title: Tremorsense
subtitle: Sense vibrations
description: A creature with Tremorsense can detect and pinpoint the origin of vibrations within a specific radius, provided that the creature and the source of the vibrations are in contact with the same ground or substance.
bullets: Tremorsense can't be used to detect flying or incorporeal creatures.
It allows a creature to locate hidden and invisible creatures that are in contact with the ground.
Many burrowing creatures like Ankhegs and Umber Hulks possess this sense.

title: Truesight
subtitle: See true forms
description: A creature with Truesight can, out to a specific range, see things as they actually are.
bullets: Sees in Darkness: Sees normally in both magical and nonmagical darkness.
Sees Invisible: Sees invisible creatures and objects.
Detects Illusions: Automatically detects visual illusions and succeeds on saving throws against them.
Perceives True Form: Sees the true form of a shapechanger or a creature transformed by magic.
Sees into Ethereal Plane: Can see into the Ethereal Plane.

title: Half Cover
subtitle: +2 AC & Dex saves
description: An obstacle covers at least half of a target’s body.
bullets: Provides a +2 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws.
Examples: a low wall, a large piece of furniture, another creature.

DM's Adjudication: To determine if a target has cover from an attacker, you must be able to trace a line from any part of the attacker's space to any part of the target's space that passes through an obstacle.

title: Three-Quarters Cover
subtitle: +5 AC & Dex saves
description: An obstacle covers about three-quarters of a target’s body.
bullets: Provides a +5 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws.
Examples: a portcullis, an arrow slit, or a thick tree trunk.
This level of cover is also sufficient for a creature to attempt the Hide action.

title: Total Cover
subtitle: Cannot be targeted directly
description: A target is completely concealed by an obstacle.
bullets: A target with total cover cannot be targeted directly by an attack or a spell.
An attack or spell can still affect a target with total cover through an area of effect if the effect can spread around the obstacle (e.g., the explosion from a Fireball).
A creature behind total cover can always attempt the Hide action.

title: Falling
subtitle: 1d6 per 10 feet (max 20d6)
description: A fall from a great height is a significant danger.
bullets: A creature takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it fell, to a maximum of 20d6.
The creature lands Prone, unless it avoids taking damage from the fall.
Rate of Falling (DMG): A creature falls 500 feet instantly on the turn it begins to fall. If still falling, it descends 500 feet at the end of each of its subsequent turns.
Flying Creatures: If a flying creature is knocked Prone or has its speed reduced to 0, it falls unless it can hover.
Homebrew - Common (Falling on a Creature): If a falling creature lands on another, the falling damage is split between them. Both must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or be knocked Prone.

title: Suffocating
subtitle: Holding your breath
description: A creature deprived of air can hold its breath and survive for a short time.
bullets: A creature can hold its breath for a number of minutes equal to 1 + its Constitution modifier (minimum of 30 seconds).
When a creature runs out of breath, it can survive for a number of rounds equal to its Constitution modifier (minimum 1 round).
At the start of its next turn after that, it drops to 0 Hit Points and is Dying.
A suffocating creature can't regain Hit Points or be stabilized until it can breathe again.

title: Underwater Combat
subtitle: Fighting in water
description: When adventuring underwater, combat is significantly affected for creatures without a swimming speed.
bullets: Melee Attacks: A creature without a swimming speed has disadvantage on melee weapon attack rolls unless the weapon is a Dagger, Javelin, Shortsword, Spear, or Trident.

Ranged Attacks: Ranged weapon attacks automatically miss targets beyond the weapon's normal range. Within normal range, the attack roll has disadvantage unless the weapon is a Crossbow, Net, or a thrown weapon like a Javelin.
Creatures and objects fully immersed in water have resistance to Fire damage.

title: Extreme Cold*
subtitle: Risk of Exhaustion
description: Creatures exposed to extreme cold must make saving throws to resist its effects.
bullets: At temperatures at or below 0° F, a creature exposed to the cold must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw at the end of each hour or gain one level of Exhaustion.
Creatures with resistance or immunity to Cold damage automatically succeed, as do those wearing appropriate cold weather gear.

title: Extreme Heat*
subtitle: Risk of Exhaustion
description: Creatures exposed to extreme heat must make saving throws to resist its effects.
bullets: At temperatures at or above 100° F, a creature exposed to the heat without enough water must make a Constitution saving throw at the end of each hour or gain one level of Exhaustion.
The DC is 5 for the first hour and increases by 1 for each additional hour.
Creatures wearing medium or heavy armor have disadvantage on the save.
Creatures with resistance or immunity to Fire damage automatically succeed.

title: Heavy Precipitation*
subtitle: Affects perception and fire
description: Heavy rain or snowfall lightly obscures the area and affects perception.
bullets: Heavy precipitation creates a Lightly Obscured area.
It also imposes disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.
It extinguishes open flames like torches and candles.

title: High Altitude*
subtitle: Risk of Exhaustion
description: Traveling at high altitudes is taxing on the body for those not acclimated.
bullets: At altitudes of 10,000 feet or higher, a creature traveling for more than 8 hours must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw at the end of the day for every hour past 8. On a failure, they gain one level of Exhaustion.
Creatures acclimated to high altitude automatically succeed on this save. A creature becomes acclimated after spending 30 days at that altitude.

title: Lingering Injuries*
subtitle: Lasting wounds from combat
description: An optional rule to add lasting consequences to grievous wounds.
bullets: A creature might sustain a lingering injury when it takes a critical hit, drops to 0 hit points, or fails a death saving throw by 5 or more.
The DM can have the player roll on the Lingering Injuries table.

Examples: Lose an Eye (disadvantage on ranged attacks and sight-based Perception), Limp (speed reduced by 5 ft), Internal Injury (disadvantage on CON saves), Horrible Scar (disadvantage on Persuasion, advantage on Intimidation).

title: Massive Damage*
subtitle: Risk of System Shock
description: This optional rule makes combat deadlier by adding consequences to taking a huge hit.
bullets: When a creature takes damage from a single source equal to or greater than half its hit point maximum, it must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw.
On a failure, the creature suffers a random effect from the System Shock table. Examples include becoming Dazed for 1 minute, or gaining a level of Exhaustion.

title: Rest Variants*
subtitle: Change game pacing
description: These optional rules change the duration of short and long rests to alter the pacing of a campaign.
bullets: Epic Heroism: A Short Rest is 10 minutes, and a Long Rest is 1 hour. This is for high-action, fast-paced games.
Gritty Realism: A Short Rest is 8 hours, and a Long Rest is 7 days. This makes encounters more dangerous and encourages careful resource management and downtime.

title: Slippery Ice*
subtitle: Difficult Terrain, risk of falling
description: Slippery ice is Difficult Terrain. When a creature moves onto it, it risks falling Prone.
bullets: Slippery ice is Difficult Terrain.
When a creature moves onto a slippery ice surface for the first time on a turn, it must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or fall prone.

title: Strong Wind*
subtitle: Affects attacks and perception
description: A strong wind imposes penalties on ranged attacks and perception, and can affect flight.
bullets: A strong wind (20+ mph) imposes disadvantage on ranged weapon attack rolls and on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.
It extinguishes open flames and disperses fog.
A flying creature must land at the end of its turn or fall.
Gale (50+ mph): A gale has the same effects, and nonmagical flight is impossible. All ranged weapon attacks are impossible.

title: Traps*
subtitle: Hidden dangers
description: Traps can be found almost anywhere and can be either mechanical or magical in nature.
bullets: Detecting/Disabling: A trap's description specifies the checks and DCs to find or disable it. Finding a trap usually requires a Wisdom (Perception) check. Disabling it may require a Dexterity check with thieves' tools, an Intelligence (Investigation) check, or a successful Dispel Magic spell for magical traps.

XGE Complex Traps: Xanathar's introduces complex traps that act on initiative, have their own actions and reactions, and can change over time, making them more like a combat encounter than a single hazard.
